Specific Details: To engage Ministers, Ministers of State and Members of Dáil Éireann and Seanad Éireann and others in local government to promote and encourage the sustainable use of Ireland's upland areas and improve and secure ongoing access to those areas which are used by Mountaineering Ireland members and other responsible recreational users.
DPOs Lobbied: Lar Power|Director of Services or Equivalent|Waterford City and County Council::Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport::Michael Ring|Minister of State|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport
Subject Matter: To engage Ministers, Ministers of State and Members of Dáil Éireann and Seanad Éireann and others in local government to promote and encourage the sustainable use of Ireland's upland areas and improve and secure ongoing access to those areas which are used by Mountaineering Ireland members and other responsible recreational users.
Intended Results: To raise awareness about the need to address path erosion and promote the sustainable use of Ireland's uplands and to work in partnership with all relevant parties to improve and secure ongoing access for recreational purposes for Mountaineering Ireland members and other responsible recreational users.
Lobbying Activities:
Mountaineering Ireland's CEO held an informal meeting, at the sidelines of another event, with Minister Paschal Donohoe (26/11/2015) and separately with Minister of State Michael Ring (26/11/2015) about ways to promote and encourage the sustainable use of Ireland's upland areas and improve and secure ongoing access to those areas for Mountaineering Ireland members and other responsible recreational users. The upland path erosion issues discussed were with specific reference to work ongoing work Errigal, Slibh Liag and Croagh Patrick. 

The CEO was also part of a pre-budget meeting with Minister Donohoe and his officials on 01/10/2016 regarding the funding of sport and sport policy. 

The CEO and the Hillwalking, Access & Conservation Officer held a meeting with senior officials in Waterford City & County Council (19/11/2016), including Lar Power, in relation to an unauthorised pathway development in the Mahon Valley|Meeting|2-5
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Mountaineering Ireland's CEO, Ruairí Ó Conchúir

Specific Details: Public Health (Alcohol) BIll, 2015
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport::Leo Varadkar|Minister|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Public Health (Alcohol) BIll, 2015
Intended Results: Greater understanding of the Bill and ensure Bill as it currently is drafted becomes Law
Lobbying Activities:
Fine Gael Ard Fheis. AAI took a stand at the Fine Gael Ard Fheis along with many other NGO's. The NGO's each had a stand which was situated in the exhibition are of the CityWest Convention centre. We paid Fine Gael a fee for attending. At the event we distributed information to delegates on the legislation and also generally on alcohol harm in Ireland. 

There we met with two Government Ministers and discussed the legislation with them. We also discussed the issue of the Road Safety Authority's partnership with Drinkaware with Minister Donohoe and how we felt this relationship was inappropriate. 

Our main contacts during the day came from members of fine gael and other delegates at the event.|Event / Reception|1
Grassroots directive: Invited members of the Public via Social Media to log onto our website and get in touch with their local TD/Senator or MEP to support this legislation

Specific Details: The scope of the UNWTO Convention is too wide and should focus exclusively on the rights and protection granted to consumers. Annex II and III of the Convention, therefore, should not expand beyond this aspect and should exclusively cover the matters already governed by the existing EU Package Travel Directive and EU Consumer Rights Directive.
DPOs Lobbied: Deirdre Clune|MEP|European Parliament::Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport::Frances Fitzgerald|Minister|Department of Justice and Equality::Kenneth Spratt|Assistant Secretary|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport::Graham Doyle|Secretary General|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport
Subject Matter: The scope of the UNWTO Convention is too wide and should focus exclusively on the rights and protection granted to consumers. Annex II and III of the Convention, therefore, should not expand beyond this aspect and should exclusively cover the matters already governed by the existing EU Package Travel Directive and EU Consumer Rights Directive.
Intended Results: To delete the references to business-to-business contractual relations contained in annex III. To change the title of the Convention to reflect this focus on consumer protection, by deleting the reference to “the protection of tourism service providers”.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Tim Fenn (Chief Executive of the Irish Hotels Federation)

Specific Details: Lobbying for the enactment of Minimum Passing Distance Law (MPDL) of a 1.5 metre safe overtaking space of bicycle riders. This would involve altering/enhancing our current overtaking law as set out in Section No.10 of SI No.182 of 1997. This would bring Ireland in line with 26 US states, 2 Canadian Provinces, 4 Australian states and territories, Portugal, France, Belgium etc.
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport::Shane Ross|Minister|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport
Subject Matter: Lobbying for the enactment of Minimum Passing Distance Law (MPDL) of a 1.5 metre safe overtaking space of bicycle riders. This would involve altering/enhancing our current overtaking law as set out in Section No.10 of SI No.182 of 1997. This would bring Ireland in line with 26 US states, 2 Canadian Provinces, 4 Australian states and territories, Portugal, France, Belgium etc.
Intended Results: To have our overtaking law altered Section No.10 of SI No.182 of 1997.::To have our rules of the road fully amended to fully reflect this MPDL (this process has already begun after some meetings)::The roll our of safe overtaking signage in Ireland as in US, Australia, France, Spain etc.::The recognition of bicycle riders as legitimate road users to others that we share the road with.::improved safety by providing a definition of a specified overtaking distance.::To provide motorists with a clear, unambiguous, easily recognised measure when overtaking cyclists in line with many jurisdictions.::To reduce the risk of cyclist/motorist crashes and also cyclist crashes caused by being side-swiped (not necessarily hit) by motor vehicles.::To ultimately assist in reducing cyclist fatalities and serious injuries.::To provide cyclists with space, a dynamic envelope, to avoid obstacles (e.g. pot-holes, glass, etc.)
Lobbying Activities: Specific emails sent to previous transport ministers, Leo Varadkar and Paschal Donohoe|Email|2-5::Meeting last year in Dáil with then Transport minister, Paschal Donohoe which was facilitated by TDs Regina Doherty and Ciaran Cannon.|Meeting|1::Through our social media page of www.facebook.com/stayinaliveat1.5 and our website of www.safecyclingireland.org, we link a suggested email to forward to the transport ministe.|Email|100+::We regularly tag relevant ministers in social media posts on MPDL and outcomes overseas.|Social Media|100+
Current or Former DPOs: Ciaran Cannon||::Regina Doherty||
Grassroots directive: Write to transport minister.    Sign a petition on Change.org.     Done through communications through social media, flyers etc.

Specific Details: Budget 2017 - IFA Submission to Government on Expenditure
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Public Expenditure and Reform::Stephen Lynam|Special Advisor|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport::Michael Noonan|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: Budget 2017 - IFA Submission to Government on Expenditure
Intended Results: Agri-Environment Schemes - GLAS - that funding of €250m is allocated for agri-environment schemes in Budget 2017, with full payments for all GLAS, AEOS and oranic scheme participants::Areas of Natural Constraints - that funding is increased by €25m in Budget 2017, to €225m, This should commence the process to restore ANC payments to pre-2008 levels::Targeted direct support for the sheep sector - that the €25m commitment in the Programme for Government for a targeted sheep scheme is introduced in Budget 2017 and that the scheme is simple and effective, with minimal costs and bureaucracy on farmers, so as to maximise its benefits.::Beef Data and Genomics Programme - that this programme is reopened in 2016 to target increased direct support for the suckler cow sector of €200/cow, this would require additional funding of €25m.::TAMS II - in order to meet the expected demand for on-farm investment, funding of €50m must be allocated to the TAMS II programme in 2017::Knowledge Transfer -  that funding of €30m is allocated for Knowledge Transfer programmes for farmers across all sectors::Producer Organisations - that the Department of Agriculture provide funding to assist farmers with the costs associated with the establishment, start up activities, and on-going running costs of producer organisations::Annual funding of €8m for the Scheme of investment aid for the development of the Commercial horticulture sector is required, due to increased investment commitments to meet sustainability standards. This scheme must also be expanded to include potatoes, specifically a targeted scheme of investment to support the development of salad, seed potatoes and potatoes for the fresh chip market.::Compensation must be provided for the disposal of ash plants in the amenity horticulture sector, which has been negatively affected by the closure of markets due to the Ash-Dieback disease.::Animal Health -  A properly funded Deer Management Programme, including targeted resources where deer are associated with TB breakdowns.::-  Increased funding allocation for the TB Eradication Programme to reduce costs for farmers maintaining calves on-farm and offsetting costs due to the prohibition on purchasing in animals::- Funding for a Department of Agriculture administered National IBR programme to safeguard access to our vital exports markets::- Increased funding for the BVD programme, recognising the extra costs incurred by farmers in repeat testing::- Strengthening of financial supports for the Johnes pilot programme, to encourage participation::- Increased funding and resources to upgrade the service provided to farmers in the Regional Veterinary Laboratories::Animal Health – Irish Equine Centre - that the state contribution for research funding for the Irish Equine Centre of €1m over a three year period is maintained.::Forestry -  Funding for a 7,000 ha planting programme::-  Funding for existing forest owner groups to realise the economic potential of private forest resource::- Funding of the Forest Road Scheme should be increased to cover the cost of the road construction and support mobilisation of private forest resource::- Funding for small scale harvesting and processing equipment to facilitate the mobilisation of non-commercial scale forests::- Funding for the establishment of a forestry forum to increase transparency in the supply chain and achieve the timber production forecasts.::Aquaculture  - that the grant aid provided by the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF), administered by BIM, must be targeted on measures that deliver more seafood for a growing market.::SAC payments - that additional funding of €5m must be allocated to the NPWS in Budget 2017 to pay farmers where restrictions to farming result from land designation.::Fair Deal Scheme – Means Assessment of farm assets - that the contribution to the cost of care under the Fair Deal Nursing Home Scheme must be immediately reviewed and must be proportionate to the ability to pay of the family farm. This would allow farm families to make the most appropriate decisions in meeting the cost of care.::Farm Assist - that, in the forthcoming review of Farm Assist, the income and child disregards that were fully abolished in Budgets 2012 and 2013 must be reinstated. In addition, IFA believes that support similar to the Family Income Supplement should be introduced for farm families whose incomes are low, but above the Farm Assist threshold.::Rural Social Scheme (RSS) - that the number of places in the RSS is increased from its current number of 2,600 to 4,000. Eligibility to partake in the RSS must be flexible to cater for farmers whose incomes, while low, are above the threshold for Farm Assist.::Walks Scheme - that, as per the commitment in the Programme for Government, the number of walks covered by the scheme must be increased to 80 and that the allocation is increased from €2m to €4m in Budget 2017.
Lobbying Activities: Letter Paschal Donohoe, Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform|Letter|1::Meeting with Paschal Donohoe, Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform|Meeting|1::Letter to Michael Noonan Minister for Finance|Letter|1::|Submission|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Joe Healy IFA President, Martin Stapleton IFA Farm Business Chairman, Joe Brady IFA Rural Development Chairman
Grassroots directive: To lobby all Oireachtas Members on IFA's Budget 2017 Submission

Specific Details: Law Society of Ireland Pre-Budget Submission 2017

Subject Matter: Law Society of Ireland Pre-Budget Submission 2017
Intended Results: The Society highlighted a number of proposals which related to regime and administrative changes to ensure that Ireland is competitive not just in relation to our corporate tax rate but in the administration of the tax system. These changes require legislative changes and cannot be implement through guidance/ebriefs.::The Society has focused on three key areas (a) Recommendations for changes to deal with inequalities or inequities which exist in the Tax Code; (b) Changes which are focused on keeping Ireland competitive and encouraging international investment; and (c)  administrative or technical issues.::The Society is very supportive of the interaction with Revenue and their officials particularly through Tax and Audit Liaison Committee (“TALC”) but are strongly of the view that it is important that tax legislation, which imposes the liability to tax and provides relief is clear from the legislation and not by virtue of other briefings.

Specific Details: Access to competitively priced finance
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance::Stephen Lynam|Special Adviser|Department of Finance::Michael W. D'Arcy|Minister of State|Department of Finance::Michael Creed|Minister|Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine::Jonathan Hoare|Special Adviser|Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine
Subject Matter: Access to competitively priced finance
Intended Results: To raise issues relating to the Irish banking sector and its impact on farming enterprises::To make the Minister aware of the market failure within the current banking environment, which is placing Irish farmers at a disadvantage to their EU counterparts. The lack of competition among financial institutions and the legacy of the historical banking losses are resulting in higher interest rates being charged to borrowers on their future borrowing requirements.::That two separate loan products would be introduced for the primary agriculture sector:::1. On-farm investment loan - this would be coherent with the programme of on-farm investment that is established under the TAMS measure in the Rural Development Programme, the Scheme of Investment Aid for the Horticulture Sector, and aquaculture grant aid under the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund.::2. Working Capital / Cashflow loan - there remains a strong demand for competitively priced working capital, which would build upon the success of the agri-cashflow loan, and further encourage farmers to improve the overall structure of their short-term financing

Specific Details: This submission draws on our unique understanding of the financial and healthcare needs, interests and concerns of our 1.3 million customers to propose progressive taxation measures which will encourage and support consumers to plan sensibly for their financial and healthcare futures.
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: This submission draws on our unique understanding of the financial and healthcare needs, interests and concerns of our 1.3 million customers to propose progressive taxation measures which will encourage and support consumers to plan sensibly for their financial and healthcare futures.
Intended Results: These measures are designed to allow the State to meet the financial and healthcare challenges arising from our aging population. In brief our recommendations are: 1.   To align exit tax on life assurance policies with DIRT / CGT; 2.     To remove the 1% levy on life assurance; 3.     To remove private bed charges for public beds; and 4.     To change the flat rate health insurance levy  to a percentage of premium.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: David Harney - CEO of Irish Life Assurance plc.

Specific Details: Fines (Payment and Recovery) Act 2014
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Public Expenditure and Reform::Charles Flanagan|Minister|Department of Justice and Equality
Subject Matter: Fines (Payment and Recovery) Act 2014
Intended Results: To vary the legislation by removing the cost to a purchaser of a search for unpaid fines that may be a charge on property.  The cost of a search can exceed €120 per transaction, and could be avoided by the Sheriff/Receiver of Fines registering a lis pendens against the property.  This would be equally effective and cost efficient to both the State and the purchaser.

Lobbyist Name: Association of Occupational Therapists of Ireland
Specific Details: AOTI Pre-Budget Submission to the Minister for Finance for budget 2018
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport
Subject Matter: AOTI Pre-Budget Submission to the Minister for Finance for budget 2018
Intended Results: Increased allocation of public funds for occupational therapy posts in acute hospitals, community mental health teams and primary care services
Lobbying Activities:
Pre-budget submission to Minister for Finance making 3 recommendations:
1. As increased hospital spending on occupational therapy reduces readmission rates, AOTI recommended that government allocate additional funds to increase the number of occupational therapists working in acute hospitals.
2. As occupational therapy significantly improves outcomes for those living in the community with serious mental illness, AOTI recommended that government allocate additional resources to enhance the recruitment of occupational therapists to community mental health teams.
2. As occupational therapy delivers better outcomes for older people with complex needs living in the community, AOTI recommended that government allocate additional funds to increase the number of occupational therapists working in primary care.|Submission|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Odhrán Allen, AOTI Chief Strategy Officer

Lobbyist Name: The Association of Farm & Forestry Contractors in Ireland (FCI) Ltd
Specific Details: Pre-Budget Submission from Association of Farm & Forestry Contractors in Ireland
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: Pre-Budget Submission from Association of Farm & Forestry Contractors in Ireland
Intended Results: The Revenue Commissioners should establish a national register of Farm Contractors based on criteria to be agreed between the Revenue Commissioners and FCI. These criteria include an insurance bond, tax compliance and VAT registration.::The Association of Farm & Forestry Contractors in Ireland (FCI) requests that the Minister for Finance and Public Reform, being aware of the cash flow challenges facing Irish dairy and livestock farmers, to make a special short term provision to allow grass and silage harvesting activities by farm contractors to be reduced to 9% for a period of two years::FCI is requesting an amendment to the annual Form 11 Tax Return and Self-Assessment Form to should include a section where farmers will be required to provide a detailed cost of their annual agricultural diesel usage costs under a new and separate heading.::FCI proposes that the Minister include a tax refund for seasonal workers who go back to work on a family farm.::FCI would like to see a change in this policy where the work of the Farm Contractor would be supported, rather than the purchase of the machines.::FCI requests that Farm Contractors who are Revenue Commissioners registered and employ a minimum of four full-time machine operators, should be allowed a similar annual Carbon Tax deduction against business profits.::The Association of Farm & Forestry Contractors in Ireland (FCI) requests that the Minister for Finance and Public Reform, through the offices of the Minister for Communications, Climate Action and Environment, provide support for the establishment of a Grass-Based Bio-Digester sector in Ireland.::FCI is requesting the creation of a dedicated Farm & Forestry Contractor Tractor Operator three-year apprenticeship programme along similar lines to that available in the Road Haulage sector.::FCI is requesting that Farm & Forestry Contractors, who are Revenue Commissioner registered, should be allowed a daily meal allowance for all of their operators in the same way that road haulage contractor’s operators are allowed a similar tax-free daily meal allowance.

Specific Details: Companies (Statutory Audits) Bill 2017
DPOs Lobbied: Charles Flanagan|Minister|Department of Justice and Equality::Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Public Expenditure and Reform
Subject Matter: Companies (Statutory Audits) Bill 2017
Intended Results: This Bill proposes that small businesses would have to apply to the High Court rather than the District Court to seek an exemption from audits. This would have a significant impact on our membership as the majority would be defined as a small business. The cost of an application to the High Court would be prohibitive and very few, if any, would be able to meet it. The VFI is asking that the approach to the Bill be reviewed & the situation as it applies today be left in place.

Specific Details: Law Society Pre-Budget Submission 2019 on issues of Probate & Taxation
DPOs Lobbied: Regina Doherty|Minister|Department of Employment Affairs and Social Protection::Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance::Heather Humphreys|Minister|Department of Business, Enterprise and Innovation
Subject Matter: Law Society Pre-Budget Submission 2019 on issues of Probate & Taxation
Intended Results: The Society focused on four key areas in making this submission,  1. Looking after those most in need.  2. Keeping Competitive and Growing.  3. Administrative and technical issues which have been raised previously, and 4.  The manner in which the Finance Bill and related legislation is introduced.::Qualifying benefits of permanently disabled individuals:  The Society recommended a reversion to the original application of Section 84 of the Capital Acquisitions Tax Consolidation Act, 2003 in respect of qualifying benefits of permanently disabled individuals.::That there is an anomaly regarding the taxation of financial dependant cohabitants,  where provision is made either by agreement or by a court order. Effectively, the current legislation encourages parties to litigate as the tax treatment is less onerous on those who proceed to Court, rather than through agreement. We see no policy rationale for the distinction.::In respect of Fair Deal:  In calculating the assets of a person applying under the Fair Deal scheme a percentage of the capital value of their house is taken into account for the first three years.  We would recommend that where a house which would qualify as a principal private residence is sold then where the sales proceeds are retained the Fair Deal applicant should be assessed on the same basis as if the house had not been sold.::A penalty exists for co-habitants where the co-owner dies:  Section 52 of the Finance Act, 2016 effectively removed the relief from all inter vivos transactions, save to a “dependant relative” as defined. As a result, qualified cohabitants continue to be excluded from the relief inter vivos and the dwelling that both live in can only pass on death.::Higher tax on qualified co-habitants on inheritances:  should a qualified cohabitant fail utterly to provide for a surviving qualified cohabitant, any application by the qualified cohabitant for provision under s. 194 of the Civil Partnership Act, 2010 will pass free from CAT. This has the outcome of encouraging a qualified cohabitant to fail to make proper provision as litigation will result in the surviving qualified cohabitant receiving proper provision free from CAT.
Lobbying Activities: See our full submission, including detailed recommendations at https://lawsociety.ie/policyandlawreform|Submission|1

Specific Details: Benefit-in-kind on professional subscriptions
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: Benefit-in-kind on professional subscriptions
Intended Results: In eBrief No. 04/18 Revenue updated their guidance for the interpretation of section 114 TCA 1997 in relation to professional membership fees. Revenue’s position on the ‘wholly, exclusive and necessarily” test is stricter than that set out in previous guidance.::The circumstances in which professional fees are viewed by Revenue as incurred ‘wholly, exclusive and necessarily’ in the carrying on of an office or employment are (1) where there is a statutory requirement for membership of a professional body or to hold a practising certificate and (2) where statutory provisions must restrict the ability of an individual to fulfil the full duties of an office or employment unless they are members of a relevant professional body.::The new Guidance does not taken into account the maintenance and promotion of standards, education and the continuing professional development of the professional sector by professional bodies. Payment of membership fees to a professional body and completion of continuous professional development is often a requirement of the professional body in order for an individual to maintain their professional qualification.::Revenue’s position on second or more memberships penalises the employee or office holder who wishes to boost their skillset with a second relevant qualification in their chosen field and who is paying a subscription fee in relation to that qualification. There is a concern that Revenue’s new guidance may lead to a decline in membership of professional bodies.::By way of comparison in the UK, a statutory list of approved professional bodies is maintained whereby subscriptions to such bodies are not treated as a taxable benefit if paid by an employer and if the activities of the body are of direct benefit to, or concern the profession practiced in, in the performance of the duties of the employment.::The stricter interpretation of the wholly, exclusive and necessarily test in relation to professional subscriptions is not welcomed by the Law Society nor is the apparent narrow view taken by Revenue on subscriptions paid to two or more professional bodies. Our tax system should help rather than hinder the development of an educated and skilled workforce in order to attract inward investment to Ireland.
Lobbying Activities:
The Society was signatory to the publication 'Building Ireland's Future - The Role of the Professions'; which detailed the value of the professions and underlined the importance of a practical approach to the tax treatment of subscriptions of professional bodies. 

See the full submission at: https://lawsociety.ie/policyandlawreform|Submission|1

Specific Details: The regulatory and reporting 'compliance load' and the costs of compliance are becoming unsustainable for many charities. The Wheel called on Paschal Donohoe, Minister for Finance, at the National Economic Dialogue to address the 'compliance load', and the unsustainable costs of compliance now being borne by charities, and to introduce a requirement for statutory funders to make a proportional contribution to the overheads of organisations they fund, in Budget 2019
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: The regulatory and reporting 'compliance load' and the costs of compliance are becoming unsustainable for many charities. The Wheel called on Paschal Donohoe, Minister for Finance, at the National Economic Dialogue to address the 'compliance load', and the unsustainable costs of compliance now being borne by charities, and to introduce a requirement for statutory funders to make a proportional contribution to the overheads of organisations they fund, in Budget 2019
Intended Results: to ensure that a process is commenced to review and streamline the multiple, and often overlapping, compliance requirements facing charities, and to ensure that all statutory funders make a proportional contribution to the overhead costs of organisations they fund
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Ivan Cooper, Director of Public Policy

To bring about changes to the tax system that could encourage relocation of key personnel to Ireland and bring equity to the tax treatment of investment product returns;::Special Assignee Relief Programme (SARP): •	Calibrate SARP to give Ireland a competitive advantage in attracting highly skilled personnel;  •	Increase the exemption level from 30% to 50%; •	Apply relief to all income, with a qualifying threshold of €75,000; •	Open SARP to new hires to allow talent to be recruited, and not just transferred from groups; •	Extend the programme to provide certainty for staff and employers; •	Provide for a tax-free allowance of €30,000 for relocation expenses;::•	Allow tax-free reimbursement of up to five return trips per year; and  •	Extend the certification window to ease application process.::Taxation of Investment Products: •	Eliminate the 1% Life Levy; and  •	Restore parity between DIRT and Exit Tax.::Property tax •	Raise concern regarding constant changes to taxation of Irish commercial property and the rates of such.::Fast-tracking of limited partnership legislation to deliver on the strategic objective of developing and growing employment under the Government’s Strategy for Ireland’s International Financial Services Sector 2015-2020

Specific Details: Save As You Earn (SAYE) Employee Share Schemes are under threat as a result of Brexit. SAYE are tax efficient savings accounts for employees. The monies are held by a qualifying institution. In this instance 2 of the 3 qualifying institutions are using their banking passporting licence to provide the service out of the UK into Ireland. When Brexit happens on the 29th March 2019, these accounts will be closed for over 12000 Irish employees.
DPOs Lobbied: Michael D’Arcy|Minister of State|Department of Finance::Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: Save As You Earn (SAYE) Employee Share Schemes are under threat as a result of Brexit. SAYE are tax efficient savings accounts for employees. The monies are held by a qualifying institution. In this instance 2 of the 3 qualifying institutions are using their banking passporting licence to provide the service out of the UK into Ireland. When Brexit happens on the 29th March 2019, these accounts will be closed for over 12000 Irish employees.
Intended Results: A specific piece of legislation needs to be put in place to protect these 12000+ employees' savings continuing to allow them to particpate in their company's share scheme, by allowing the 2 UK banks to continue to offer the current SAYE service in Ireland after Brexit.
Lobbying Activities: The Irish ProShare Association jointly signed a letter requesting the Minister for Finance to meet with us and representatives from our membership to discuss the issue and possible solutions to save the SAYE accounts of the over 12000 employees affected by Brexit.|Letter|1

Specific Details: Save As You Earn (SAYE) Employee Share Schemes are under threat as a result of Brexit. SAYE are tax efficient savings accounts for employees. The monies are held by a qualifying institution. In this instance 2 of the 3 qualifying institutions are using their banking passporting licence to provide the service out of the UK into Ireland. When Brexit happens on the 29th March 2019, these accounts will be closed for over 12000 Irish employees.
DPOs Lobbied: Michael D’Arcy|Minister of State|Department of Finance::Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: Save As You Earn (SAYE) Employee Share Schemes are under threat as a result of Brexit. SAYE are tax efficient savings accounts for employees. The monies are held by a qualifying institution. In this instance 2 of the 3 qualifying institutions are using their banking passporting licence to provide the service out of the UK into Ireland. When Brexit happens on the 29th March 2019, these accounts will be closed for over 12000 Irish employees.
Intended Results: A specific piece of legislation needs to be put in place to protect these 12000+ employees' savings continuing to allow them to particpate in their company's share scheme, by allowing the 2 UK banks to continue to offer the current SAYE service in Ireland after Brexit.
Lobbying Activities: The Irish ProShare Association jointly signed a letter requesting the Minister for Finance to meet with us and representatives from our membership to discuss the issue and possible solutions to save the SAYE accounts of the over 12000 employees affected by Brexit. The letter was issued to the Minister for Finance, the Minister of State for Financial Services and the UK treasury on the 19th Sept 2018, requesting a meeting with all 3. A meeting was later scheduled with the Minister for State for Financial Services at 5pm on the 3rd December 2018 which was attended by Gill Brennan CEO Irish ProShare Association, Ashley Price of Yorkshire Building Society and Chris Mowatt of Barclays Bank plc - the latter 2 being the UK qualifying institutions holding the SAYE accounts on behalf of Irish employees working for UK businesses operating in Ireland offering SAYE as part of their benfits package.|Letter|1

•	urgently address the unsustainable rise in insurance premiums facing charities.
•	incentivise mergers and cover the costs of mergers by providing a dedicated budget in 2019 to support mergers for those charities that wish to enter into merger arrangements with other charities.

Specific Details: Participation in the Revenue Commissioner's Tax Administration Liaison Committee (TALC) - various updates sought and views shared.
DPOs Lobbied: John Hogan|Assistant Secretary|Department of Finance::Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Public Expenditure and Reform::Michael Gladney|Commissioner|The Office of the Revenue Commissioners
Subject Matter: Participation in the Revenue Commissioner's Tax Administration Liaison Committee (TALC) - various updates sought and views shared.
Intended Results: The Society participates in the Revenue Commissioner's Main TALC, Indirect Taxes Sub-Committee and the Direct/Capital Sub-Committee. The nature of the meetings are to update and receive clarification from the Revenue Commissioners on aspects of tax administration. As a DPO and other public officials interact with the TALC from time to time, the meetings are recorded here for information purposes only.
Lobbying Activities: The function of the TALC Committee is to review and make recommendations to achieve more effective and efficient administration of the direct taxes, stamp duties, and value added tax. These may relate to either administrative practices of the Office of the Revenue Commissioners or of tax practitioners. Membership is at a senior level from the Office of the Revenue commissioners and appropriate bodies representing tax practitioners. The Committee keeps under consideration its current membership and any requests for amendments or extension. Minutes of meetings are available online at: http://www.revenue.ie/en/practitioner/talc/main-talc-minutes.html|Meeting|2-5::|Letter|2-5

Specific Details: Renewables Submission - Budget 2019
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance::Michael W. D'Arcy|Minister of State|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: Renewables Submission - Budget 2019
Intended Results: To highlight that IFA sees a role for farmers in achieving the targets set down in the EU Energy Directive which mandates Ireland to achieve 16% of our energy requirements from renewable sources, by 2020.::That farmers could achieve these targets through farm-scale, community or farmer-led Renewable Electricity Projects (REE) projects.::That IFA's proposals for REE projects would be taken on board as follows:::* Feed-In Tariffs - proposed price support bidding process put forward by the Department of Communications, Climate Action and Environment is not suitable for REE projects. Such projects would not have the economies of scale to successfully compete in a competitive bidding process.::In order to deliver on Government’s ambition of promoting economic development and supporting community and citizen participation in the transition to a low carbon economy it is essential such projects are not part of the competitive bidding process. A guaranteed Feed-In Tariff must be delivered.  The generation Feed-In Tariff should be 17c/kWh, guaranteed for 20 years and linked to CPI. An increased generation Feed-In Tariff for roof mounted solar projects, should also be introduced.::* Technology specific base price::Current renewables policy supports a least cost and technology neutral approach to the delivery of renewable energy in Ireland. This is not compatible with Government’s energy policy objective of broadening and diversifying the renewable technology mix and cannot be achieved if there is a continuation of the least cost strategy, which has resulted in vast disruption to rural communities and the reliance on a single technology, large scale on-shore wind.::The IFA does not support the proposal to hold technology neutral auctions. Instead the process should include a guaranteed base price for REE projects, and discriminate in favour of alternative energy sources including solar, hydro and anaerobic digestion.::To deliver on the Government’s high-level commitment of supporting REE projects, a budget of €100m should be ring-fenced from the current PSO levy funds collected. This represents approximately one-fifth of the overall budget. This ring-fencing should also be extended beyond total capacity of each auction, to include ring fencing at connection point (substation etc) to include REE projects.::* Grid connection policy::Grid connection policy should be linked directly with landowners who gave the original permission for the grid connection application to be made. This would prohibit speculative trading of grid connections.::The proposal to universally impose bid bonds or penalties should be reviewed, as it would be a disproportionate cost burden for certain projects. For REE projects, the proposal for bid bonds and penalties should be removed as this requirement may act as a barrier to adoption.::* Opportunities for micro-energy generation::The development of a micro-generation renewables sector in Ireland will support the rural economy and also provide an opportunity for a wider number of citizens to displace their fossil fuel use. There is need for a budget and implementation timeframe for micro-generation, in line with Government policy.::A clear statement of intent is required for micro-energy generation, which includes: •	A ring-fenced budget from the PSO levy •	Timeframe for implementation  •	Planning and development charges exemption for all farm-scale renewable projects •	Grid connection preference and waivering of connection costs for farm-scale projects::* Financial supports for community-led projects::The provision of finance for REE projects will be essential to support early stage adoption. This must be complemented by the introduction of a robust Feed-In Tariff structure, which includes an increased tariff REE projects and roof-mounted solar projects.   There would also be an on-going requirement for the terms and cost finance to be monitored, to ensure the project financing costs remain competitive.::The terms of existing investment mechanisms, such as the Employment and Investment Incentive Scheme, should be tailored to accommodate the inclusion of investments for REE projects.::* Community participation in renewable energy::Community participation in renewable energy production must be at the centre of future Government policy. To achieve this IFA proposes an additional generation Feed-In Tariff of 2.5c/kWh, in addition to the standard generation Feed-In Tariff.::REE projects, grid access and electricity infrastructure costs should be waivered and grid access should be ring-fenced. Furthermore such projects should be supported through the innovation process through the provision of information and advice to help guide and assist projects during uncertainty.::In addition, a requirement for an annual community contribution during the duration of large-scale renewable projects should be mandatory and legislated for. This contribution should be the greater of 1.5% of turnover or €2/MWh. This annual contribution should be used to support rural regeneration, working closely with initiatives such as the LEADER programme.

Specific Details: In January 2018, the European Commission proposed that the freedom for EU member states to classify bottled Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) in the reduced rate category would be withdrawn. In Ireland, this would mean that LPG cylinders would be taxed at 23% versus the current rate of 13.5%. Cylinder LPG is a vital commodity for homeowners and businesses not connected to the natural gas network. The proposed VAT change would further increase rural energy costs and worsen the urban/rural divide.
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: In January 2018, the European Commission proposed that the freedom for EU member states to classify bottled Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) in the reduced rate category would be withdrawn. In Ireland, this would mean that LPG cylinders would be taxed at 23% versus the current rate of 13.5%. Cylinder LPG is a vital commodity for homeowners and businesses not connected to the natural gas network. The proposed VAT change would further increase rural energy costs and worsen the urban/rural divide.
Intended Results: Calor is calling on the Department of Finance to oppose measures which would necessitate a change of domestic policy in relation to VAT on LPG cylinders and which would have a negative impact on Irish consumers and GHG emission levels. Consumption of LPG per household is highest in rural counties unserved by the natural gas grid and counties with the lowest average incomes correspond closely to those with a higher usage rate for LPG.

Specific Details: European Union (Anti Money Laundering: Beneficial Ownership of Trusts) Regulations 2018 (the 'Regulations')
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: European Union (Anti Money Laundering: Beneficial Ownership of Trusts) Regulations 2018 (the 'Regulations')
Intended Results: The primary purpose of the draft Statutory Instrument is to give effect to paragraph 1 of Article 31 of Directive 2015/849. The Society, as competent authority for monitoring solicitors' compliance, made the following submissions::A transitional period of 6 months from the date of commencement of the Regulations should be provided for.::Additional clarity and guidance required in relation to the term 'take reasonable steps' to obtain and hold relevant information in Regulation 3(1).::Confirmation and explicit reference in the regulations that 'beneficial owners' do  not include non-natural persons such as, for example, charitable organisations.::Clarify whether the administration of estates of deceased persons is encompassed by the Regulations.::Clarify and reduce, where feasible, the onerous impact on pensions, in particular occupational pensions and members.  The Society urges the Department to consider a simplified due diligence procedure, considering their low risk designation.::The Society recommends inserting a safeguard for legal professional privilege to ensure that access does not extend to any material which is protected by legal professional privilege.::The Society expressed the need for careful consideration in the matter of permitting public access to the Register, drawing from concerns made by other parties in Ireland, UK and in Europe.
Lobbying Activities: Read the Society's submissions, and keep informed of our law reform activities at https://www.lawsociety.ie/Solicitors/Representation/Policy-and-Law-Reform/|Submission|1

Specific Details: Participation in the Revenue Commissioner's Tax Administration Liaison Committee (TALC) - various updates sought and views shared.
DPOs Lobbied: John Hogan|Assistant Secretary|Department of Finance::Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance::Michael Gladney|Commissioner|The Office of the Revenue Commissioners
Subject Matter: Participation in the Revenue Commissioner's Tax Administration Liaison Committee (TALC) - various updates sought and views shared.
Intended Results: The Society participates in the Revenue Commissioner's Main TALC, Indirect Taxes Sub-Committee and the Direct/Capital Sub- Committee. The nature of the meetings are to update and receive clarification from the Revenue Commissioners on aspects of tax administration. As a DPO and other public officials interact with the TALC from time to time, the meetings are recorded here for information purposes only.
Lobbying Activities:
The function of the TALC Committee is to review and make
recommendations to achieve more effective and efficient
administration of the direct taxes, stamp duties, and value added tax.
These may relate to either administrative practices of the Office of the
Revenue Commissioners or of tax practitioners.

Membership is at a senior level from the Office of the Revenue commissioners and
appropriate bodies representing tax practitioners. The Committee keeps under consideration its current membership and any requests for amendments or extension. Minutes of meetings are available online at: http://www.revenue.ie/en/practitioner/talc/main-talcminutes.

To read the Society's submissions, and keep informed of our law reform activities at https://www.lawsociety.ie/Solicitors/Representation/Policy-and-Law-Reform/|Meeting|2-5

Subject Matter: Streamlining the conveyancing process.
Intended Results: Remove statutory charge on certain property to provide clear title for buying and mortgaging new homes by first time buyers.::It is the Society's submission that the statutory clawback outlined in the attached draft note should be removed from legislation because of the long established principle that a purchaser for value without notice should be protected by law.::Pending the removal of the statutory charge from legislation, the Society recommends that Revenue should, as an interim measure, issue written assurance that they will not exercise the charge without first getting a judgment and registering it against the property.
Lobbying Activities: To see the Society's other law reform activities see: https://www.lawsociety.ie/Solicitors/Representation/Policy-and-Law-Reform/|Letter|1

Intended Results: Limit cost to consumer of getting a release of mortgage from IBRC in special liquidation.::IBRC  are leving a charge of €2,000 +VAT for a letter of non-crystallization/vacate/discharge.  Loans which were originally with INBS or Anglo Irish, were taken over by IBRC, who now claim requests for such releases are 'third party requests'. Specific Details: Section 58 of the Withdrawal of the UK from the EU (Consequential Provisions) Act 2019. If s.58 is commenced a minimum Euro threshold will be introduced under the Retail Export Scheme (a scheme which allows qualifying travellers (being tourists resident outside the EU) to claim a refund of VAT charged on goods purchased in Ireland) which would have serious adverse consequences for Fexco's tax refund business.
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: Section 58 of the Withdrawal of the UK from the EU (Consequential Provisions) Act 2019. If s.58 is commenced a minimum Euro threshold will be introduced under the Retail Export Scheme (a scheme which allows qualifying travellers (being tourists resident outside the EU) to claim a refund of VAT charged on goods purchased in Ireland) which would have serious adverse consequences for Fexco's tax refund business.
Intended Results: Fexco requested that an industry wide consultation process be commenced during which we can consider alternative avenues (other than the introduction of a monetary threshold) that could be pursued to address any concerns the Government may have and to consider any precautionary measures which could be introduced should the UK not introduce a VAT retail export scheme in a no-deal Brexit situation.
Lobbying Activities: Letter sent by courier on 5th April 2019 to outline Fexco's concerns in relation to S. 58 of the Withdrawal of the UK from the EU (Consequential Provisions) Act 2019|Letter|1::This matter was also discussed at follow up meetings on the evening of the 11 April 2019 and morning of 12 April 2019 in Killorglin, Co. Kerry.|Meeting|2-5
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Denis McCarthy, CEO, Fexco on behalf of Fexco Tax Free Shopping Unlimited Company

Specific Details: Pre-Budget 2020 Submission specifically recommending certain amendments to legislation governing the Key Employee Engagement Programme (KEEP) and removal of PRSI and USC from existing revenue approved share plans. IPSA also recommends the introduction of an Employee Ownership Trust model promoting employee ownership, similar to the UK model.  It is our view that a similar scheme is necessary in Ireland particularly for businesses in rural Ireland.
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: Pre-Budget 2020 Submission specifically recommending certain amendments to legislation governing the Key Employee Engagement Programme (KEEP) and removal of PRSI and USC from existing revenue approved share plans. IPSA also recommends the introduction of an Employee Ownership Trust model promoting employee ownership, similar to the UK model.  It is our view that a similar scheme is necessary in Ireland particularly for businesses in rural Ireland.
Intended Results: The proposed amendments to the KEEP legislation are designed to enable a broader cohort of small and medium sized companies to be in a position to utilise this legislation The proposed amendments to the revenue approved schemes are designed to have a positve impact on the participation rates in these schemes.Measures that enhance employee ownership benefit the entire Irish economy, not just start- ups or early stage companies in the FinTech and InsurTech sectors.

Specific Details: Submission to the Public Consultation Paper on CGT Entrepreneur Relief
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: Submission to the Public Consultation Paper on CGT Entrepreneur Relief
Intended Results: The Society would like to secure CGT Entrepreneurs CGT, this in the Society's view could be achieved by:::The removal of the 50% working requirement of the time in a managerial or technical capacity in the business for 3 out of a 5 year period prior to the disposal. It is excessively restrictive::We would also suggest that the cap on relief (a lifetime threshold of €1,000,000) is too low in light of the position with the equivalent relief in the UK. Placing a cap of this level on the Relief has already been acknowledged by the Minister for Finance publicly as something on which change is required.::Encouragement of Passive Investors: The amendments to the EII/SURE structures in recent years through the GBER have served to dissuade investment in the SME sector by passive investors. Anecdotally, the complexity of such structures and lack of certainty on tax outcomes on investment have given rise below optimal levels of investment.

Specific Details: Macra na Feirme Pre-Budget 2020 Submission
DPOs Lobbied: Michael Creed|Minister|Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine::Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance::Katherine Zappone|Minister|Department of Children and Youth Affairs
Subject Matter: Macra na Feirme Pre-Budget 2020 Submission
Intended Results: On Farm Nutrient Management Infrastructure: Macra na Feirme calls for a fast track system of applying for TAMS scheme for young farmers and farmers participating in the voluntary AASAP program.  This fast tracking of applications will make it easier for farmers to benefit and also encourage more farmers to get involved in this voluntary programme.::Sexed Semen: Macra na Feirme propose that Sexed Semen be VAT exempt for all farmers. The use of sexed semen on Irish Farms has the potential to improve animal welfare and reduce our greenhouse gases emissions by allowing farmers to breed the replacements or animals for finishing that they need, reducing the number of stock bred overall.::Farmer Health, Safety and Wellbeing: There is a extraordinary need to address the health, safety and wellbeing of our farmers through training, education and innovation. There are many aspects outside the farmers gate out their control which can add additional pressures and strain on the farmers health and wellbeing. Macra na Feirme propose to develop a National Rural Network for Ireland, this development would require urgent funding.::Stamp duty relief:  The extension of the current 100% young farmer stamp duty relief to young trained farmers under the age of 35 for the transfer of land to the year 2023.  To expand the current stamp duty relief to include all land transfer in registered Succession Farm Partnerships up to the age of 40, to allow more young farmers to enter through partnerships.::Extend the maximum age to avail of Stamp Duty relief on the purchase of land to all young trained farmers up to age of 40, to allow young farmers to build the resources required to purchase land.::Youth Services Grant Scheme: Macra na Feirme support the National Youth Council of Ireland proposal for €11.5m additional investment each year from 2019-2020 in youth work by the Department of Children and Youth Affairs.  All youth organisations including Macra na Feirme avail of the Youth Service Grant scheme annually but this grant has been reduced significantly since the economic crash.  Urgent investment is needed to restore basic services to rural young people dramatically cut in 2011::Rural Broadband: The Rural Broadband scheme should target investment in carrier neutral network providers to swiftly build a fibre-optic infrastructure in rural areas that all telecom network operators can access.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Thomas Duffy, National President; Denis Duggan, Chief Executive; Derrie Dillon, Head of Policy; Jennifer Keegan, Policy Officer

Specific Details: Budget 2020 and related matters
DPOs Lobbied: Leo Varadkar|Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach::Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: Budget 2020 and related matters
Intended Results: A phased approach to the €40 million Brexit fund, that was promised in Budget 2020, be implemented with half being allocation whether deal or no deal and the balance payable on a hard Brexit outcome.::No current budget increase in 2020 for tourism, unless a no deal Brexit comes about. Brexit, deal or no deal, is already damaging Irish tourism & increased current funding is needed in 2020 to halt the decline in the sector.::Other sectors receiving additional funding in 2020 however tourism sector has not received anything other than 'no deal Brexit funding'. This should be reconsidered to ensure appropriate changes are made to tourism budget.::Supplemental funds of €7 million allocated by end of 2019. With no budget increase for tourism in 2020 these supplemental funds at the end of 2019 in fact mean that in 2020 there will be a decline in current tourism investment by the exchequer. This needs to be reviewed and clarified by Government.::More commitment to the industry is critical to the health of tourism jobs and businesses particularly in regional Ireland.

Subject Matter: The Restart Grant that was released in the last few weeks carries a number of conditions that exclude many busiensses which have been severely impacted by COVID-19.
Intended Results: The cap on turnover, number of employees etc needs to be reviewed and there is a strong case for the support to be applied differently across the various sectors.  The travel sector has been hit particularly hard and taking the example of travel agents, in many cases their turnover excludes them, despite the fact that margins are low and as a sector it will be slower to recover thatn many others.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Brian O'Farrell & network of Chambers across Ireland

Specific Details: We wrote to the Minister for Finance to follow up on previous correspondence calling for permanent debt cancellation for developing countries in the light of the Covid-19 epidemic
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: We wrote to the Minister for Finance to follow up on previous correspondence calling for permanent debt cancellation for developing countries in the light of the Covid-19 epidemic
Intended Results: We called on the Irish government to use its influence to support the call for: - an immediate and permanent cancellation of all principal, interest and charges for the remainder of 2020 for all countries in need, and most urgently for PRGT and IDA countries. - to push for extension of this offer to payments due on multilateral debt in 2020, including those of the IMF and World Bank (WB).
Lobbying Activities: We emailed the Minister for Finance providing more detail on our previous letter calling for debt relief, and responding to his letter to us.|Email|2-5
Grassroots directive: Email the Minister for Finance asking him to: (1) Cancel all debt payments for countries suffering from the economic impacts of coronavirus, due in 2020.  (2) Help countries in trouble to restructure their debt rather than bailing out lenders. (3) Ensure new finance, granted to tackle the coronavirus, does not create more debt.

Specific Details: A pre Budget submission focusing on the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on employee share schemes such as the Key Employee Engagement Programme (KEEP) and on short-term measures that could be implemented to help companies who are suffering imminent cash consolidation issues as well as certain other short term amendments that could be implemented to Revenue approved employee share plans. Reminders also on legislation required to future proof SAYE schemes post-Brexit and the new register of trusts.
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: A pre Budget submission focusing on the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on employee share schemes such as the Key Employee Engagement Programme (KEEP) and on short-term measures that could be implemented to help companies who are suffering imminent cash consolidation issues as well as certain other short term amendments that could be implemented to Revenue approved employee share plans. Reminders also on legislation required to future proof SAYE schemes post-Brexit and the new register of trusts.
Intended Results: In times when cash consolidation is of key concern, the ability to offer equity in a tax efficient manner to staff can be an essential lifeline. 	A new COVID specific incentive would be a lifeline to struggling companies. One alternative worth looking at is a very simplified salary for shares scheme - others would be a reform of the current KEEP scheme.	In respect of all-employee Revenue approved schemes, temporary COVID-19 measures should be introduced to allow employees take saving holidays.

Lobbyist Name: Property Owners Association of Ireland Limited (IPOA)
Specific Details: The Budget
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: The Budget
Intended Results: •	Rental loss incurred as a result of rent forgiveness, or as a result of the additional rent arrears protections provided by the State due to Covid-19, should be allowable as an expense.::•	Treat letting property as a business.  Remove the restriction imposed by section 97 on rental business and treat the rental business in the same manner as any other business::•	Allow an exemption from Income Tax for Long-Term Leasing Structures to encourage long-term leasing, changing the mindset of property owners.::•	Allow Local Property Tax as a deductible expense.::•	Building Energy Rating – monies spent on making a rental property more energy efficient should be allowable in the Tax year of expenditure.::•	Allow market rent restoration on the sale of property.::•	Accelerated Capital Allowances should be introduced for new capital expenditure to increase the supply of accommodation::•	Pension Provision – rental income should be treated as reckonable income for pension purposes.::•	Allow Capital Payment as an expense prior to computing rental income.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Stephen Faughnan Chairman Irish Property Owners' Association

Specific Details: Covid Restrictions Support Scheme (CRSS) - Relevant Turnover Amount
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance::Leo Varadkar|Minister|Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment::Damien English|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Covid Restrictions Support Scheme (CRSS) - Relevant Turnover Amount
Intended Results: For businesses that only commenced trading in 2019 or 2020 the relevant turnover in order to receive the CSSR payment would be relatively small and not reflect the actual weekly sales. Businesses that started in 2020 again would have smaller turnover and the weeks they were closed due to Covid restrictions would not be taken into account. We called on the Minister to revisit this aspect as it has the potential to unfairly impact on what would be a small number of operators.

Specific Details: Waiving of court fees for licences renewal for 2020
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: Waiving of court fees for licences renewal for 2020
Intended Results: The government announced a support package for pubs which included the waiving of licence fees, including Public Music & Singing Licences. Some members are being billed for those licences as they do not appear to be included in the enabling legislation of the finance Bill 2020. Section 20 covers most of the licences, but not this one. We call on the Minister to confirm that was an oversight and to have the necessary amendments made.

Specific Details: IMO Pre-Budget 2021 Submission
DPOs Lobbied: Stephen Donnelly|Minister|Department of Health::Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Public Expenditure and Reform
Subject Matter: IMO Pre-Budget 2021 Submission
Intended Results: Immediate awarding of consultant status to Specialists in Public Health Medicine and the full implementation of the recommendations of the Crowe Horwath Report on the Role, Training and Career Structures of Public Health Physicians (2018)::Investment in acute bed capacity including temporary builds, a doubling of ICU capacity and capital finance for 5000 inpatient beds including stand-alone hospitals for elective care::Address the shortage of hospital consultants through:  targeted measures to recruit and retain hospital consultants; reverse the pay disparity between consultants employed prior to and post October 2012; Ensure all SpRs who have finished training are offered a temporary consultant locum post; Increase the number of basic and specialist training posts to meet future demand.::Supports for General Practice and the shift of care into the community through resourcing of diagnostic, radiology and laboratory departments to allow GPs  timely access to investigations; Ensure Acute Medical Units (AMUs) and Acute Surgery Units (ASUs) are appropriately resourced with clear referral pathways for patients requiring urgent care; Supports for GPs to employ additional GPs, practice nurses and other support staff;  supports for newly establishing GPs.::Planning  for the Health and Social Care needs of an ageing population including further resourcing of rehabilitative care beds and home care supports including intensive home care packages to allow older people remain at home as long as possible;  Investment in a holistic approach to care with input from a range of specialties including geriatricians and public health specialists; Investment in a programme of GP care for nursing home patients that reflects the complexity of care required.::Increase resources for specialist community mental health services to ensure teams are staffed with the full multidisciplinary compliment of staff as recommended in A Vision For Change.::Investment in electronic health records across hospitals and community health centres;  Upgrading of IT infrastructure, both hardware and software, to support safe remote-consultations and multi-disciplinary team-working;  Ensure on-going investment in the development of eHealth in General Practice in line with the agreement between the IMO, the HSE and the Dept::Appropriately resource Prevention Programmes through increased Community Medical staffing levels to maintain the quality and safety of child health and vaccination programmes and investment in diagnostics and treatment pathways are needed to support the full re-opening of life-saving cancer -screening programmes.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Vanessa Hetherington, Assistant Director, Policy and International Affairs

Lobbying Activities: 03/9/2020 letter by Peter Vale (Partner, Grant Thornton) as Chair of CCAB-I Tax Committee to Brian Boyle (Assistant Secretary, Revenue Commissioners) re: impact of lockdown restrictions on ability to meet tax compliance deadlines (re: Corporation Tax deadlines and re: Income Tax deadlines). Letter focused on the application (and proposing the suspension) of surcharges, and flagging of other potential negative knock-on consequences (and proposing actions to limit these consequences) associated with potential late filings. Letter focused on proposing the suspension of surcharges associated with potential late filings, and on proposing the suspension of time-bound correspondence to taxpayers, such as re: Temporary Wage Subsidy Scheme (TWSS) compliance checks. Letter not directly on behalf of Grant Thornton or client(s) of Grant Thornton.|Letter|1::22/10/2020 letter by Peter Vale (Partner, Grant Thornton) as Chair of CCAB-I Tax Committee to Paschal Donohoe (Minister of Finance, Department of Finance) on Budget 2021 changes to the Intangible Assets Allowance regime, and flagging potential negative implications for Ireland as a location for intangible assets. Specific Details: Letters by Peter Vale (Partner, Grant Thornton) as Chair of CCAB-I Tax Committee to Minister of Finance and senior Revenue Commissioners officials, re: (3) Finance Bill 2020 re: Covid Restrictions Support Scheme, transfer pricing exclusions, withdrawal of payment of interest on tax refunds, and (4) statistical returns (VAT Return of Trading Details, Form 46G) re: tax debt warehousing schemes. Activity not directly on behalf of Grant Thornton or client(s) of Grant Thornton.
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance::Joe Howley|Assistant Secretaries or Equivalent Grades|The Office of the Revenue Commissioners
Subject Matter: Letters by Peter Vale (Partner, Grant Thornton) as Chair of CCAB-I Tax Committee to Minister of Finance and senior Revenue Commissioners officials, re: (3) Finance Bill 2020 re: Covid Restrictions Support Scheme, transfer pricing exclusions, withdrawal of payment of interest on tax refunds, and (4) statistical returns (VAT Return of Trading Details, Form 46G) re: tax debt warehousing schemes. Activity not directly on behalf of Grant Thornton or client(s) of Grant Thornton.
Intended Results: Intended result to provide guidance on and to Influence developments re: (3) proposing amending conditions of Covid Restrictions Support Scheme, re-evaluation of transfer pricing exclusion changes (further discussions with CCAB-1), and alignment of  interest rates paid / levied re: successful / unsuccessful appeals, and (4) proposing taxpayers with outstanding statistical returns not denied access to debt warehousing schemes if other compliance requirements met within specified timescales.
Lobbying Activities: 02/11/2020 letter by Peter Vale (Partner, Grant Thornton) as Chair of CCAB-I Tax Committee to Paschal Donohoe (Minister of Finance, Department of Finance) on matters arising out of the Finance Bill 2020 re: the Covid Restrictions Support Scheme (CRSS), transfer pricing exclusions, withdrawal of the payment of interest on tax refunds due to taxpayers. Letter proposed amending conditions of the CRSS, re-evaluation of changes re: the transfer pricing exclusions in context of further discussions involving CCAB-1, and a fair balanced alignment of the associated interest rates paid and levied re: successful and unsuccessful appeals. Letter not directly on behalf of Grant Thornton or client(s) of Grant Thornton.|Letter|1::20/11/2020 letter by Peter Vale (Partner, Grant Thornton) as Chair of CCAB-I Tax Committee to Joe Howley (Collector-General, Revenue Commissioners) suggesting leniency for taxpayers re: outstanding statistical returns such as the VAT Return of Trading Details and third party returns such as Form 46G re: tax debt warehousing schemes. The letter proposes that taxpayers with such returns still outstanding are not denied access to debt warehousing schemes if all other compliance requirements are met within the specified timescales. Letter not directly on behalf of Grant Thornton or client(s) of Grant Thornton.|Letter|1

Intended Results: To demonstarte that there is no viable alternative to agri-diesel. Therefore, the carbon tax does not incentivise behavioural change and is penal on farmers.::The current rebate system for carbon tax on agri-diesel is cumbersome and is not open to all farmers or agri-contractors. As a result, many farmers are unable to claim back the carbon tax paid or pay for it indirectly because it is passed on by agri-contractors. Nevertheless, it is imperative that the current rebate system is maintained in the absence of an exemption.::That agri-diesel should be exempt from carbon tax.

Specific Details: On the 23rd September - we hand delivered copies of our pre-budget submission to - Minister Heather Humphries, DRCD  - Minister of State Joe O Brien, DRCD  - Minister Paschal Donohoe, Finance  - Minister Stephen Donnelly, Health  - Minister Michael McGrath, Public Expenditure and Reform
DPOs Lobbied: Heather Humphreys|Minister|Department of Social Protection::Joe O'Brien|Minister of State|Department of Rural and Community Development::Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance::Michael McGrath|Minister|Department of Public Expenditure and Reform::Stephen Donnelly|Minister|Department of Health
Subject Matter: On the 23rd September - we hand delivered copies of our pre-budget submission to - Minister Heather Humphries, DRCD  - Minister of State Joe O Brien, DRCD  - Minister Paschal Donohoe, Finance  - Minister Stephen Donnelly, Health  - Minister Michael McGrath, Public Expenditure and Reform
Intended Results: The Wheel called on Government to: 1. Provide adequate and sustainable funding for the sector.  2. Streamline regulatory and funding-related compliance requirements and provide for the costs of compliance.  3. Bring down the cost of insurance.  4. Comprehensively resource the new strategies for the community and voluntary sector and social enterprise.  5. Implement the recommendations of the Report of the Independent Review Group  on the Role of Voluntary Providers in Publicly Funded Services::The Wheel called on Government to: 4. Comprehensively resource the new strategies for the community and voluntary sector and social enterprise.  5. Implement the recommendations of the IRG Report. 6. Develop a framework for collaborative working and provide resources and supports for mergers.  7. Increase budget allocations for Department of Rural and Community Development::The introduction of similarly proportional increases to the Community Employment Scheme (CE) and the Rural Social Scheme (RSS), as well as changes to the way the schemes are currently run, including recommendations on: training, reporting requirements, Garda vetting, recruitment and referral practices, IT systems, flexibility around the time and duration of schemes, facilitation of participation of older people in the schemes, uniformity of implementation and financial compensation.
Lobbying Activities: On the 23rd September - we hand delivered copies of our pre-budget submission to - Minister Heather Humphries, DRCD  - Minister of State Joe O Brien, DRCD  - Minister Paschal Donohue, Finance  - Minister Donnelly, Health  - Minister McGrath, Public Expenditure and Reform|Submission|1

Specific Details: We wrote to the Minister for Finance to follow up on previous correspondence calling for permanent debt cancellation for developing countries in the light of the Covid-19 epidemic
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: We wrote to the Minister for Finance to follow up on previous correspondence calling for permanent debt cancellation for developing countries in the light of the Covid-19 epidemic
Intended Results: We called on the Irish government to use its influence to support the call for: - an immediate and permanent cancellation of all principal, interest and charges for the remainder of 2020 for all countries in need, and most urgently for PRGT and IDA countries. - to push for extension of this offer to payments due on multilateral debt in 2020, including those of the IMF and World Bank (WB).
Lobbying Activities: We arranged an email campaign targeting the Minister for Finance highlighting the global week of action on debt cancellation in the light of COVID|Email|2-5
Grassroots directive: Email the Minister for Finance asking him to: (1) Cancel all debt payments for countries suffering from the economic impacts of coronavirus, due in 2020.  (2) Help countries in trouble to restructure their debt rather than bailing out lenders. (3) Ensure new finance, granted to tackle the coronavirus, does not create more debt.

Specific Details: Availability of CRSS to people who are passing on the family business.
DPOs Lobbied: Leo Varadkar|Minister|Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment::Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: Availability of CRSS to people who are passing on the family business.
Intended Results: An anomaly has occurred where Revenue is penalising pubs who have taken the decision to pass on the family business. When the new family member transfers the licence to their name Revenue is not waiving the fee. Also the CRSS payment is based on 2019 turnover and Revenue have taken the view that the new licence holder had no income in 2019 so is not entitled to CRSS, despite the fact the pub was trading and made returns to Revenue in 2019. This anomaly needs to be addressed without delay.

Specific Details: The supports around the re-opening of the pub trade.
DPOs Lobbied: Leo Varadkar|Minister|Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment::Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance::Catherine Martin|Minister|Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media::Brian Murphy|Chief of Staff|Department of the Taoiseach::John Kelly|Acting Assistant Secretary|Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media::Tanya Warren|Special Adviser|Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media::Juno McEnroe|Special Adviser|Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media
Subject Matter: The supports around the re-opening of the pub trade.
Intended Results: We outlined the financial supports required regarding the CRSS, a continuation of mortgage payments breaks until restrictions are listed, support for employees until they can get back to work and a need for some indication as to what stage in the vaccination process the sector might re-open.

Specific Details: Licence & Business Transfer / Seasonal Outlets - CRSS
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance::Leo Varadkar|Minister|Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment::Catherine Martin|Minister|Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media
Subject Matter: Licence & Business Transfer / Seasonal Outlets - CRSS
Intended Results: Each year there a number of licence & business transfers, normally from one generation to the next which are normally seamless. Revenue are deciding that the new business had no turnover for 2019 & ad are not entitled to CRSS. There are also a number of outlets in tourist areas that do little or no business during the off season. Revenue have decided these are not entitled to CRSS either. This is a major anomaly that needs to be addressed without delay.
