Specific Details: Misean Cara calls on the Government to increase ODA and to establish a roadmap to meet its ODA/GNI commitments
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: Misean Cara calls on the Government to increase ODA and to establish a roadmap to meet its ODA/GNI commitments
Intended Results: An increase in ODA in real terms to allow Ireland to keep pace with global needs now and in the post-COVID environment, and benchmarks by which to meet its ODA/GNI commitments, in support of the SDGs.::An increase funding to missionary bodies' in light of their enduring commitment to tackling poverty, inequality and injustice in the world.::Financing for climate change mitigation and adaptation to support Least-Developed Countries (LDCs) and Small Island Developing States (SIDS). This is critical to addressing the climate emergency, recognising the intricate relationship between the impacts of climate change - poverty and conflict.
Lobbying Activities:
Letter dated 16/08/21.
With specific regard to Budget 2022, Misean Cara urges Government to:    
1.	Deliver an increase in ODA in real terms to allow Ireland to keep pace with global needs now and in the post-COVID environment, and benchmarks by which to meet its ODA/GNI commitments, in support of the SDGs. 
2.	Ensure additional and targeted financing for climate change mitigation and adaptation to support Least-Developed Countries (LDCs) and Small Island Developing States (SIDS). This is critical to addressing the climate emergency, recognising the intricate relationship between the impacts of climate change - poverty and conflict.
3.	Act on the recommendation of the Joint Oireachtas Committee on Foreign Affairs and Trade, and Defence when, in its Review of the Irish Aid Programme, it recommended in 2018 that the Government 'examine opportunities to increase funding to missionary bodies' in light of their enduring commitment to tackling poverty, inequality and injustice in the world.|Letter|1

Subject Matter: Section 127B of the Taxes Consolidation Act 1997

Specific Details: Budget
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: Budget
Intended Results: A new rate of rental tax of 25% be introduced for rental profit going forward to encourage private investors to stay in the market.  To facilitate equal treatment of investors and retention of supply.::Introduction of roll over relief in relation to Capital Gains tax in circumstances whereby the investor acquires another property within two years for residential rental purposes. This will encourage investors to reinvest in the market.::Reduce Capital Gains tax on sale of investment properties in areas of high owner occupier demand. This will encourage investors to sell properties that will be suitable for owner occupiers and first-time buyers.::Refurbishment Incentives – encourage property owners to refurbish properties through a double credit relief on amounts spent above €10,000 (similar to double rent relief schemes) to improve the standard of rental properties.::Treat letting property as a business instead of as Unearned Income.::Pension Provision – rental income should be treated as relevant income for pension purposes. Furthermore, the Government should abolish the recently introduced legislation prohibiting the purchase of investment properties directly through small, self-administered pension schemes.::Introduce Double Taxation relief for Letting Agent Fees to help retain landlords in the sector struggling with complex, confusing legislation.

Specific Details: Letter by Peter Vale (Partner, Grant Thornton) as Chair of CCAB-I Tax Committee to Minister of Finance to make representations on matters arising out of the Finance Bill 2021. Activity not directly on behalf of Grant Thornton or client(s) of Grant Thornton.
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: Letter by Peter Vale (Partner, Grant Thornton) as Chair of CCAB-I Tax Committee to Minister of Finance to make representations on matters arising out of the Finance Bill 2021. Activity not directly on behalf of Grant Thornton or client(s) of Grant Thornton.
Intended Results: Arising out of the Finance Bill 2021 request for treatment of self-assessed tax payers re: Working from Home Relief, request for review of de-minimis amount re: interest limitation rules (ILR), request for review of  current arrangements re: the taxation of leasing transactions.
Lobbying Activities: 5/11/2021 Letter (sent by email) by Peter Vale (Partner, Grant Thornton) as Chair of CCAB-I Tax Committee to Minister of Finance Paschal Donohoe to make representations on matters arising out of the Finance Bill 2021. Request that in respect of Working from Home Relief the self-assessment is not varied and that self-assessed tax payers are not obliged to automatically submit supporting evidence of a claim with tax returns. Request for the de-minimis amount re: interest limitation rules (ILR) associated with EU’s Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive to be looked at and amended re: 'cliff edge' aspects. Flagging continuing issues (and consensus that legislative amendments required) re: taxation of leasing transactions as previously raised by the CCAB-I with Revenue through the TALC forum and with the Department of Finance through the Leasing Working Group. Activity not directly on behalf of Grant Thornton or client(s) of Grant Thornton.|Letter|1

Lobbyist Name: Irish National Organisation of the Unemployed
Specific Details: The INOU was part of a delegation from the Community and Voluntary Pillar that met with Minister for Finance, Paschal Donohue T.D. and the Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform, Michael McGrath T.D. to discuss Budget 2022 under five headings: framing, investment and resourcing; income adequacy; services; infrastructure; recognition and resourcing of the sector.

Subject Matter: The INOU was part of a delegation from the Community and Voluntary Pillar that met with Minister for Finance, Paschal Donohue T.D. and the Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform, Michael McGrath T.D. to discuss Budget 2022 under five headings: framing, investment and resourcing; income adequacy; services; infrastructure; recognition and resourcing of the sector.
Intended Results: To secure a more equitable and inclusive Budgetary process and address the social and economic exclusion facing so many unemployed people and other people distanced from the labour market.

Specific Details: IPSA is a not-for-profit organisation which advocates for employee share ownership. IPSA made a budget submission on behalf of its members to the Minister for Finance requesting various changes to the SAYE and KEEP. IPSA believe that the KEEP is an extremely beneficial and important scheme for SMEs. However, many potential candidates who have been keen to avail of the scheme have been unable to, due to not being able to meet the onerous conditions.
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: IPSA is a not-for-profit organisation which advocates for employee share ownership. IPSA made a budget submission on behalf of its members to the Minister for Finance requesting various changes to the SAYE and KEEP. IPSA believe that the KEEP is an extremely beneficial and important scheme for SMEs. However, many potential candidates who have been keen to avail of the scheme have been unable to, due to not being able to meet the onerous conditions.
Intended Results: Support the continuation of the Save as You Earn (SAYE) scheme, by working to replace the departing Ulster Bank as the sole Irish-licensed bank acting as savings carrier to SAYE. Introducing an alternative medium for savings, for example, investigating scope for the NTMA to manage the SAYE cash deposits and support SAYE.  Clarify and simplify legislation surrounding the KEEP scheme .

Specific Details: Pricing of Electricity and its impacts on Homes and Businesses
DPOs Lobbied: Leo Varadkar|Minister|Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment::Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance::Michael McGrath|Minister|Department of Public Expenditure and Reform
Subject Matter: Pricing of Electricity and its impacts on Homes and Businesses
Intended Results: Grow awareness amongst Policy Makers of the impacts of inaction in the Electricity System. We are concerned about rising & volatile wholesale pricing of electricity and its impacts on energy users.
Lobbying Activities:
Letter to the Minister for Enterprise on the scope of proposed Energy Subsidy Scheme and Green Transition funds for SMEs.  We asked that these grants should be opened to more SMEs not just those in targeted sectors or segments.|Letter|1::Pre-Budget Submission to the Minister for Finance and the Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform. 

The Submission focuses on five key proposals that Pinergy believe will be key to creating an energy market that is fair and delivers choice for the 2.4 million electricity customers in the country. The proposals from Pinergy include a temporary reduction in VAT on electricity to zero, a temporary wholesale price cap on electricity prices as well as targeted and universal supports for electricity customers this winter. In addition, Pinergy is urging Government to now make further & significant capital investment in the electricity infrastructure as well a review of the current market structures to ensure a fairer energy marketplace for all.|Submission|1

Specific Details: Retail Banking Review - Department of Finance
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: Retail Banking Review - Department of Finance
Intended Results: To welcome the review initiative suggesting existing Retail Banking model including governing parameters/regulations underpinning same are not fit for purpose. The footprint/presence of 3 remaining Banks are also far removed from previous positions, and their retraction in the market is having a significant impact on many rural towns and villages where they close branches.::-	Big concern re lack of Competition in the market – B&A research suggests overall positive relationships between Banks & Consumers, however suggested output may have been somewhat different if question re rates have been asked when you consider SME rates here vs. international peers. Output may also be very different for ‘transactional type customers' and those seeking loans/in financial difficulty. Feedback regularly received re increasing information requirements; delays in decision-making.::-	Highlighted also considerable Rural vs. Urban divergence in B&A findings which needs to be taken into consideration in future reviews, with increasing digital offering/trajectory not attractive to all – demographic; vulnerable customers; connectivity issues etc.::-	Called out B&A finding that only 4% experienced in Switching and huge difficulty that is having currently with Ulster Bank / KBC exit. Said feedback from FB committee members is significant delays in arranging meetings to open up new Business current accounts (up to 2/3months in cases); and that existing Bank switching offer isn't really fit for purpose.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Rose Mary McDonagh IFA Farm Business Chair, Shane Whelan IFA Policy Executive,

How are the Government going to deal with the increased demand given the impending shortages /blackouts were are to expect in the Winter period.::Talent & Skills   -  Further funding is required  for Recruitment, Training & Development across all sectors  but we especially need  additional funding for hospitality recruitment and career awareness, and targeted resources for training and skills development. What is coming on stream to address the issues and how can we expedite the designation?

Intended Results: Increase of the Daily Expenses Allowance by €20.00 (or by the same amount other payments are increased in budget 2023; Child benefit (or International Protection Child Payment) for all children in the protection process to make universal child benefit truly universal; •	Ensuring that community and voluntary organisations are fully resourced to support people fleeing war in Ukraine;  •	Increase in civil legal aid for protection applicants and resources to the Legal Aid Board.

Specific Details: We work in the areas of renewable fuels for transport, renewable gas (biomethane) and plant protein, bringing awareness of the opportunities for Ireland to shift to a more climate friendly system and greater energy independence, in a way which allows for sustainable economic growth and innovation.
DPOs Lobbied: Eamon Ryan|Minister|Department of Environment, Climate and Communications::Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: We work in the areas of renewable fuels for transport, renewable gas (biomethane) and plant protein, bringing awareness of the opportunities for Ireland to shift to a more climate friendly system and greater energy independence, in a way which allows for sustainable economic growth and innovation.
Intended Results: We help policy makers understand the industrial, technological and market environments so they can devise better renewable fuels, gas and plant protein policies.   The Climate Action Plan and the EU Green Deal and the key legislative frameworks of interest.
Lobbying Activities: Informal chance encounters at events.  For instance I met Minister Ryan by chance on a plane and at a conference and we had brief conversations.|Informal communication|2-5::I send occasional info-emails to a number of government officials, elected representatives and public organisations (Climate Change Advisory Council, SEAI).  In addition to providing information on renewable energy and plant protein independence I invite them to visit production facilities to see first hand how the processes work.|Email|2-5::I submitted a response to the December public consultation on the planned Jan 1st increase in the renewable fuels obligation.|Submission|1::I regularly publish policy relevant comment on my LinkedIn profile, reaching a dozen or so key influencers of policy direction in Ireland and the EU.  It is difficult to get direct access to policy makers.  For instance, in 2022 the government conducted a study on renewable fuels, refraining from an engagement with sector experts, and basing its findings wholly on Internet searches.  This leads to blindspots.   I try to counter this.|Social Media|6-10

Specific Details: The INOU was part of a delegation from the Community and Voluntary Pillar that met with Minister for Finance, Paschal Donohue T.D. and the Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform, Michael McGrath T.D. to discuss Budget 2023 under three themes: Budget 2023 – approach, principles, and fiscal stance; income adequacy, social protection and the cost of living; investment in services and infrastructure.
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Finance::Michael McGrath|Minister|Department of Public Expenditure and Reform
Subject Matter: The INOU was part of a delegation from the Community and Voluntary Pillar that met with Minister for Finance, Paschal Donohue T.D. and the Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform, Michael McGrath T.D. to discuss Budget 2023 under three themes: Budget 2023 – approach, principles, and fiscal stance; income adequacy, social protection and the cost of living; investment in services and infrastructure.
Intended Results: To secure a more equitable and inclusive Budgetary process and address the social and economic exclusion facing so many unemployed people and other people distanced from the labour market.
Lobbying Activities: The INOU's Pre-Budget submission had been sent to the Ministers for Finance and Public Expenditure and Reform in advance of the meeting and the organisation used the opportunity to urge the Ministers to properly address the issue of income inadequacy facing so many unemployed people and others of working age trying to manage on a social welfare payment, which the cost of living crisis has exacerbated.|Virtual Meeting|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Bríd O'Brien, Head of Policy and Media

Lobbyist Name: Irish National Organisation of the Unemployed
Specific Details: In June the INOU attended the National Economic Dialogue (NED), the theme was ‘the economy in 2030 - enabling a sustainable future for all’. The INOU participated in two workshops: Better Public Service Delivery: Maximising the Impact of Public Spending; and Leveraging digital in the future of work and employment service delivery.
DPOs Lobbied: Heather Humphreys|Minister|Department of Social Protection::John McKeon|Secretary General|Department of Social Protection::Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Public Expenditure, NDP Delivery and Reform::Michael McGrath|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: In June the INOU attended the National Economic Dialogue (NED), the theme was ‘the economy in 2030 - enabling a sustainable future for all’. The INOU participated in two workshops: Better Public Service Delivery: Maximising the Impact of Public Spending; and Leveraging digital in the future of work and employment service delivery.
Intended Results: To ensure the economic and social issues facing unemployed people were raised at the National Economic Dialogue. Throughout NED four Ds were referenced: demography; decarbonisation; digitalisation; and deglobalisation. Each of these will impact on the type of labour market Ireland will have in 2030, each presents challenges and opportunities for the type of work people will be able to access, and whether or not it supports them to live their lives to the fullest extent possible.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Bríd O'Brien, Head of Policy and Media

Subject Matter: The INOU was part of a delegation from the Community and Voluntary Pillar that met with Minister for Finance, Michael McGrath T.D. and the Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform, Paschal Donohoe T.D. to discuss Budget 2024 under three themes: Budget 2024 – enabling a sustainable future for all:  approach and principles, and taxation; income adequacy, social protection and the cost of living; investment in services and infrastructure.

Specific Details: GPCareforAll wishes to raise the viability of services due to the impact of the legislative changes introduced by section 1008A TCA 1997 of the Finance (No. 2) Act 2023.  These changes will have a detrimental impact GPCareForAll and its ability to operate. The charity and its model has a track record of creating GP practices in areas of deprivation which are grossly underserved; deprived populations do not present an attractive investment proposition for GPs or commercial organisations.
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: GPCareforAll wishes to raise the viability of services due to the impact of the legislative changes introduced by section 1008A TCA 1997 of the Finance (No. 2) Act 2023.  These changes will have a detrimental impact GPCareForAll and its ability to operate. The charity and its model has a track record of creating GP practices in areas of deprivation which are grossly underserved; deprived populations do not present an attractive investment proposition for GPs or commercial organisations.
Intended Results: In order to ensure that GPCareforAll can continue to exist by ensuring that the charity is not be subject to the provisions of section 1008A, one option would be to issue confirmation through an agreed concession followed by a legislative amendment that the transitional arrangements which apply up 31 December 2023 can continue to apply only in circumstances where the medical practice is a “registered charity”.
Lobbying Activities: We met in a private residence in Phibsborough to discuss the issue. |Meeting|1

Specific Details: Poultry Sector - Employment Permits
DPOs Lobbied: Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Public Expenditure, NDP Delivery and Reform
Subject Matter: Poultry Sector - Employment Permits
Intended Results: To highlight employment permits and the increased rates of payments associated in the given timelines which are totally unworkable.::To emphasise that permitted non-EU employees in the food industry work alongside colleagues from Ireland and from other EU Member States on similar wage levels.::To highlight that the recent change to legislation in relation to permitted employees will result in a situation whereby people doing the same job may be working on different wage levels (the difference between current minimum wage level and proposed minimum permit wage level is circa €2/hr).::To point out that, aside from the very obvious economic impact of the changes on businesses, this will have serious unintended consequences. This increase will not just apply to those on employment permits, it will impact the sector's wage bill as others in the workforce will look for the same increase. In implementing this change, the Government are putting in jeopardising our Irish produce, and making us more vulnerable to imports.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Nigel Sweetnam IFA Poultry Chair, Sarah Hanley IFA Policy Executive

Lobbyist Name: Irish National Organisation of the Unemployed
Specific Details: In May the INOU attended the National Economic Dialogue 2024 in Dublin Castle: participated in the Breakout session on Poverty and income inequality: trends and challenges in light of recent economic shocks, chaired by Minister for Social Protection and Minister for Rural and Community Development, Heather Humphreys T.D.; and the final plenary session.
DPOs Lobbied: Heather Humphreys|Minister|Department of Social Protection::John McKeon|Secretary General|Department of Social Protection::Paschal Donohoe|Minister|Department of Public Expenditure, NDP Delivery and Reform::Michael McGrath|Minister|Department of Finance
Subject Matter: In May the INOU attended the National Economic Dialogue 2024 in Dublin Castle: participated in the Breakout session on Poverty and income inequality: trends and challenges in light of recent economic shocks, chaired by Minister for Social Protection and Minister for Rural and Community Development, Heather Humphreys T.D.; and the final plenary session.
Intended Results: To ensure economic and social issues facing unemployed people were raised at NED: 2024 theme was “A more shock-prone world: challenges and opportunities for Ireland”. The background paper stated “The objective is to explore how Ireland can adapt to the evolving ‘new normal’ which is likely to be very different from the old. The key message is that economic resilience must be top of the policy agenda.” It is vital that social inclusion, equality, environmental sustainability are also prioritised.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Bríd O'Brien, Head of Policy and Media
